notes: The story had the working titles 'The Trilogic Game' and 'The Toymaker'.
Only the fourth episode, 'The Final Test', exists in the BBC Archives as an incomplete 16mm black-and-white film telerecording.
This was the first of six Doctor Who scripts to be written by Brian Hayles, and (out of those six) one of only two not to feature the Ice Warriors.
The original script featured the characters from Gerald Savory's 'George and Margaret', but permission to use them was denied.
The original storyline was very different, and much more adult and satirical in scope.
The Trilogic game was inspired by the Tower of Hanoi.
Michael Gough enjoyed working on the story so much that he encouraged his then-wife Anneke Wills to take the role of Polly.

continuity_notes: The Doctor cries out in pain in the cliffhanger that concludes the story, later revealed to be caused by a toothache triggered by biting into a sweet, an event for which he will need a dentist.

After being conditioned by the artificial intelligence WOTAN on 20 July 1966, Dodo suffered a nervous breakdown and left the TARDIS, her claims to have played games with living dolls and other similarly outlandish stories resulting in her being sent to a psychiatric institution.

plot.plot_summary: The Doctor has been mysteriously rendered invisible, though Steven and Dodo can still hear his voice. They realize they are in the world of the Celestial Toymaker, an evil entity who traps people and turns them into his playthings. The Toymaker forces them to play a series of games, with the threat that if they lose, they will become his playthings forever. They must navigate through challenges involving living dolls, chairs that can kill, and a TARDIS hopscotch game, all while the Doctor is trapped playing the Trilogic game against the Toymaker. In the end, the Doctor is able to defeat the Toymaker and escape with Steven and Dodo.
